title: 110_hr2939
content: The Act titled "Atlantic Blackfish Conservation Act" prohibits the commercial harvesting of Atlantic blackfish. The Atlantic Blackfish Conservation Act prohibits the commercial harvesting and sale of Atlantic blackfish, also known as tautog, in specific waters. Violators may face civil penalties up to $1,000 per violation. The civil penalty for violating the Atlantic Blackfish Conservation Act can be up to $1,000 per violation. The Secretary of Commerce determines the penalty amount based on various factors, including the nature of the violation and the violator's history of prior violations. The violator's ability to pay and other relevant factors are also taken into consideration. The process for reviewing civil penalties and options for payment, compromise, and subpoenas are outlined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Civil penalties for violating the Atlantic Blackfish Conservation Act can be up to $1,000 per violation, determined by the Secretary of Commerce based on factors like the nature of the violation and the violator's history. The violator's ability to pay is considered. Failure to pay assessment, compromise, and subpoenas apply to penalties assessed under subsection (a) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. Vessels and fish involved in unlawful acts under subsection (a) are subject to civil forfeiture to the United States. District courts have jurisdiction over forfeiture proceedings. States have jurisdiction over forfeiture proceedings under this subsection, following procedures outlined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission must amend the Interstate Fisheries Management Plan for Atlantic blackfish to comply with the prohibition set forth in section 2. The term "coastal State" in this Act refers to Pennsylvania, States bordering the Atlantic Ocean north of South Carolina, the District of Columbia, and the Potomac River Fisheries Commission. "Coastal waters" include all waters shoreward of the baseline for each coastal State and the waters of the coastal State. The coastal State includes waters seaward from the baseline to the exclusive economic zone, waters within the District of Columbia's jurisdiction, and waters of the Potomac River under the Potomac River Compact of 1958.
